Title:
Higher-level molecular phylogeny of darkling beetles
(Coleoptera, Tenebrionoidea, Tenebrionidae)
Abstract:
Though insects are a major group whose diversity
represents about 60% of the estimated million and a half described
eukaryotic species world-wide, comprehensive and well-resolved
intra-ordinal phylogenies still lack for the majority of insect groups.
It is especially the case for the most speciose insect group, the
beetles (Coleoptera), a group for which less of than 4% of the known
species have been sequenced. In this study, we reconstruct the first
molecular higher-level phylogeny for the species-rich darkling beetles,
a family comprising at least 20,000 species. Although amongst all
families of beetles the family ranks seventh in terms of species
richness, the lack of knowledge on the phylogeny and systematics of the
group is such that its monophyly is questioned (not to mention those of
the subfamilies and tribes). We investigate the evolutionary history of
Tenebrionidae using multiple phylogenetic inference methods (Bayesian
inference, maximum likelihood and parsimony) to analyse a dataset
consisting of eight gene fragments across 404-taxa (including 250
tenebrionid species). Although the resulting phylogenetic framework only
encompasses a fraction of the known tenebrionid diversity, it provides
important information on their systematics and evolution. Whatever the
methods used, our results provide a strong support for the monophyly of
the family, and highlight the likely paraphyletic or polyphyletic nature
of several important tenebrionid subfamilies and tribes. It is
especially the case for the polyphyletic subfamilies Diaperinae and
Tenebrioninae, which clearly require substantial revision in the future.
Some unexpected associations in several higher groups are also evidenced
by the phylogenetic analyses, such as the pairing of Opatrini with
Bolitophagini. Our study also advances our knowledge of the evolution of
the group, providing novel insights to discuss much-debated theories,
such as the apparent relict distribution of the tribe Elenophorini.
